This is one of those times where you wish there was a neutral option, so I'll round up and do a positive. In general, I'm having fun. I'm enjoying exploring, and doing side quests, and sneaking around as Naoe the way Assassin's Creed games are supposed to be.

That being said, whoever designed the combat for this entry forgot what Assassin's Creed is about. Playing on normal difficulty, the combat doesn't feel like AC. It feels like a soulslike game. If this was a soulslike franchise I'd understand, but I don't play AC for forced boss fights that are 90% dodge rolling while you slowly, excruciatingly, chip away at someone whose skin is made of steel. If I wanted soulslike, no offense but there are better options. 

Anyways, since you can tune combat difficulty separate from the other options, it's at least salvageable, but I sincerely hope this kind of design doesn't become their new trend.

If you‚Äôre a fan of the franchise or just love open-world action/stealth set in an evocative historical setting, Assassin‚Äôs Creed Shadows delivers a very good experience for me. Not every game is going to be perfect to everyone. It's all subjective.

That said, it may not reach the heights of masterpiece status for everyone. The story fades a bit, the mission structure can feel familiar, and some design choices will frustrate those seeking more innovation.

Overall, it‚Äôs a good game, and I honestly don‚Äôt understand the wave of hate that crashed down on it.
Yes, I know why it happened. But if you put all that aside, it‚Äôs actually quite an interesting game.

The story is solid engaging enough.
There are plenty of side quests and contracts, and I really like how well they‚Äôre put together.
The combat system is a mixed bag: sometimes it shines, sometimes it frustrates. Still, it‚Äôs flashy, and I‚Äôm usually excited to get into a fight rather than annoyed by it.

The only real downside for me is the level-gating. High-level areas simply aren‚Äôt worth visiting ahead of time.
Stealth is the weakest part of the game: sometimes it‚Äôs trivial, and sometimes hiding becomes impossible, even when no one is actually looking at you.

The world has become more complex and varied - lots of activities, seasonal changes that enhance both visuals and gameplay.

Of course, there are bugs. A game of this scale simply cannot exist without them. I‚Äôve never seen a completely bug-free open-world game. Even the much-praised RDR2 is full of bugs - we just tend to overlook them.

The music is excellent, though Ubisoft rarely misses the mark in that department.

I‚Äôd give this game a 7 out of 10 
 not perfect, but undeniably engaging.

Shadows ‚Äî the Assassin‚Äôs Creed of feudal Japan.
Naoe and Yasuke. Between Kuji-kiri and Katas, between corrupt bandits and samurai clans, between conspiracies and dark secret organizations working against the empire.

For me ‚Äî and of course in this review I am speaking only for myself ‚Äî Assassin‚Äôs Creed Shadows is the best Assassin‚Äôs Creed I have ever played.

I can‚Äôt relate to all the ‚Äúcriticisms‚Äù and reviews from gaming journalists. Most of them are completely exaggerated, and the community often just repeats what they hear instead of forming their own opinion.

A quick word about myself: I discovered AC around 2012 and started with AC III. Definitely one of the great entries, but in my personal ranking it‚Äôs fairly far down the list. I played AC Black Flag only during long gaming nights at a good friend‚Äôs house, never on my own ‚Äî but it was still a unique Assassin‚Äôs Creed. After that, I took a long break and truly came back with AC Origins. And I was hooked. I‚Äôve always been fascinated by history, and seeing Assassin‚Äôs Creed brought to ancient Egypt was simply brilliant. It‚Äôs definitely one of the most beautiful AC titles ever released.

With Origins followed by Odyssey, Ubisoft did so much right, and I played both entries for countless hours. But an Assassin‚Äôs Creed with samurai and ninjas had always been a ‚Äúchildhood wish‚Äù of mine. I‚Äôve been fascinated by that era of human history since I was young, and I always hoped Ubisoft would give us exactly that kind of Assassin‚Äôs Creed. Few settings fit the Assassin‚Äôs Creed fantasy better than feudal Japan.

And finally, it‚Äôs here.
The story is incredibly well written. The emotional journey with Naoe ‚Äî dealing with the murder of her father, the brutality of war, the destruction, and the suffering of civilians ‚Äî combined with the story of the unusual samurai Yasuke, constantly motivates you to keep going.

The combat mechanics and finisher moves are consistently fun every single time they happen. The game keeps offering challenges, and the balance between a stealthy assassin silently eliminating targets and a samurai who can crush five or six enemies at once is just awesome.

The hideout-building system offers hours of satisfaction as you construct your own little ‚Äúdomain‚Äù in the middle of Japan.

The world looks absolutely beautiful. Roaming and riding through the landscapes is pure joy. The seasons and the corresponding loading screens during transitions are visually stunning ‚Äî like walking through a living painting.

At the time of writing, I haven‚Äôt finished the Claws of Awaji DLC yet, but even the beginning and the new island continue to add excitement to the game. After AC Valhalla, this feels like the right answer. Valhalla wasn‚Äôt bad, but it was clearly a step back compared to its predecessors. Shadows, for me, makes it a delight to jump back in again and again, and it fulfilled all my expectations, hopes, and wishes for an Assassin‚Äôs Creed set in Japan.

For me personally ‚Äî a fully subjective opinion ‚Äî this AC is number one and definitely my favorite in the entire series.
I hope Ubisoft continues on this path and that the upcoming titles will be just as good as AC Shadows.

With that said, thank you for taking the time to read this review. Feel free to check out my profile, and I wish you all the best ‚Äî stay healthy!

Why do we continue to play Assassin's Creed franchise?
Maybe it's not wrong to oppose Ubisoft's policies in the first place, but we shouldn't forget that Assassin's Creed, with all its shortcomings, has given us beautiful years, and perhaps after all these years, it is still very enjoyable to experience a new work from this popular franchise, at least for me.

Shadows, unfortunately, is far from the core of Assassin's Creed, as if it were a prelude to a more detailed game that has not yet been released. I understand that Japan fever and samurai and shinobi culture have been sweeping the world for some time, and Ubisoft wanted to get a share of this trend.

After all this, Assassin's Creed Shadows has become a good game in its own right. An attractive combat system with unique weapon and clothing designs for both characters.
Side missions that this time were not boring to me like in previous games, and a deep and extremely beautiful design of the environment that dazzles the eye, although the weakness of parkour in navigating this environment should not be overlooked.

The stealth system and many options for doing it caught my attention a lot. Even up to this point, after 150 hours of game experience, I still haven't gotten enough of the game's attractive stealth tricks.

The great attention to the character's personality, especially Naoe, makes the player not take the story lightly and try to get to know each character and their relationship with the main character of the game. However, the motion capture of the characters often appears disappointing, and the voice acting of the game, at least the English dub, is such that the characters' voices do not dissolve in the ambiance of the environment, and as a musician and sound engineer, this weakness of the voice acting was very clear to me.

Overall, for me, who has been immersed in the world of this franchise for nearly 20 years, the game was extremely enjoyable and I recommend it to action-adventure fans.

Genuinely surprised me in a really good way. The setting in feudal Japan is incredibly well done and the world actually feels alive. The dual protagonist system works genuinely well. Being able to play stealthy one moment and then switch to a more direct combat approach keeps it fresh and fun. Both styles feel refined, not like one was just added on top of the other.

The game looks fantastic, The visuals are truly stunning where the atmosphere pulls you in immediately, and the soundtrack supports everything without overdoing it. Parkour and stealth finally feel closer to what AC used to be while still feeling modern. I haven‚Äôt had any performance issues and even the smaller side content has been worth my time.

If you‚Äôve liked any of the stronger and older AC titles or just want a well-made open world action game, I‚Äôd honestly recommend this.

Graphics:

Music:

Solid traditional Japanese soundtrack. Best moments are when theres a bit of rock mixed in or the Japanese-African fusion you get when playing Yasuke. 

Story: 

Clumsy structure and pacing. Picking your main targets on the menu made them feel like side quests. Yasuke's story had its moments but not enough to carry while hiding Naoe's true ending behind DLC was a sorry move. Easily the low point of the game.

Overall: a generous 8/10. An overall fun and pretty good entry into the AC franchise. But it could've been great if they had just structured the story better and didn't hide Naoe's true ending behind DLC.

Let me start of by saying that you should not buy this game unless it's on sale. For what it manages to accomplish as the best option of the Open World RPG Looter AC games, it's story falls very-very-flat until the 11th hour, as it makes it glaringly obvious that the Open World RPG Looter AC Games (yet again) fail to capitalize and capture the essence of what makes Assassin's Creed "[b]Assassin's Creed[/b]".

I sunk a total in-game hours at around 73.5hrs with total play-time at 101.5hrs, between my lengthy pauses, other idling, in-game time is measured by active in-world time. Let it be known I played with the new Advanced Parkour update, Canon Mode, and Instant Assassinations turned on. I am a core believer that you cannot have an Assassin's Creed game where you cannot [b]assassinate[/b] your target. In a game. About Assassins. and killing targets. As well as removing dialog options from Assassin's Creed 'cause that's not what The Animus is supposed to be. You don't get to choose history, it already happened. Also social stealth was once again abandoned. "hide in plain sight"....yeah....lol. Also Animus Confession scenes still don't exist.

An Assassin's Creed game that forgets entirely what Assassin's Creed is about.

This brings me to my first hatred that modern-day AC games need to stop, excluding Mirage from this conversation.

In regards to the main antagonists, "The Shinbakufu", only 1 out of the entire 12 are you actually allowed to Assassinate freely as if it were a Black Box mission from previous entries like Mirage, Syndicate, or Unity. But it was ULTRA stripped down where you can bait the guy to you, and kill him. The rest of them are open combat boss fights with giant pools of health. For the love of all things Assassin's Creed [h3]STOP. DOING. THIS.[/h3] I don't care how many side-objectives there are in the game that allows me to Assassinate the target without an open boss fight, if the main targets say "Assassinate [Person]" as the objective, LET. ME. ASSASSINATE. THE. TARGET. IT'S NOT THAT HARD. The only other time it let me do this pulled me into a cutscene death of the target. Which is novel, sure, BUT I DIDN'T GET TO ASSASSINATE ANYONE ELSE.

2nd problem I have with AC: Shadows is the music. There's nothing memorable about the music, and quite frequently pulls me out of the moment when some cross-genre music starts playing between traditional instruments and hip-hop. The only time I actually felt like the music fit properly was in the Epilogue of the game where Shadow's version of Ezio's Family plays. Ezio's Family is timeless, and occasionally the open world ambient music will play a few cords from it. But otherwise it's forgettable.

3rd problem I have with Shadows is in regards to the story. Nothing about the story feels coherent enough to be a narrative driven AC game, 'cause the game bombards you with so many side-quests and Organizations that you have to take down. There are 17 side-organizational circles that are not The Shinbakufu. And the story doesn't follow a narrative structure at all until Act 3 and the Epilogue, which by that point the game is basically finished. Templars are relegated to side plots and THE LITERAL END OF THE GAME, and so are the Assassins. Don't expect this game to be about Assassins vs Templars, because it's not. Ignore the fact that this takes place after Ezio's and Shao Jun's time and the Assassin Brotherhood vs Templars has been going on for HUNDREDS OF YEARS BY NOW. At least you play as an Assassin this time, or the descendent of one. But you don't learn anything about the Japanese Brotherhood or Naoe's Assassin heritage until the 11th hour of the game. Also the Japanese Brotherhood, by time of the game, is already destroyed because of a twat's inability to reconcile with the fact he's single and socially inept that you, once again, don't learn about till the 11th hour of the game. Basically everything Assassin and Templar related activities are not until the end of the game, and when it was doing it...the game felt like Assassin's Creed again. But then the game ended.

Where's the rest?

The game just also...significantly lacks any cinematics at all, or maybe it was just too spaced out given how expansive the game world is. The majority of engagement you have with the game will be two characters talking face-to-face (standing or sitting) with no other animations other than their face with procedurally generated movements. There's no walking and talking, nor set pieces engaged with.

While I can continuously go on about how bad modern-day Assassin's Creed games have become, but I will talk about the good.

I like the characters (except Gennojo), but the vast majority of them, including the antags, were forgettable. At least the way they were laid out, the allies are okay. Canon Mode completely disables romances in all forms, which I'm glad 'cause I don't care about that. Anyways, Gennojo sucks. He's some developer's self-insert asshole who's trying to be Robin Hood but kills himself in a fit of rage and starves poor people as an act of sticking-it-to-the-man and the game wants us to feel bad about it? He's also a womanizer. The game literally labels him as a womanizer in his description. Worst alley in the history of Assassin's Creed.

The Ally System returns, but it needs some TLC. Characters aren't Assassins. They do not act as such. Only one of them actually is, but all the characters just spawn in with a cloud of smoke when called instead of running in from off-camera.

The armors and cosmetics in the game, really good. Naoe's especially. Wish there were some with a little less rope and knives everywhere, but overall no complaints. I got the Assassin Initiate and Apprentice Robes and never took them off until the end when I got Naoe's Master Assassin robes.

The parkour was...better and then got some TLC from the devs post launch, which Mirage will also be getting, and it made it felt good again. Parkour gave us autonomy again. Expression. Though the world itself didn't allow for much, I hope the changes are carried into the future. So it's less thinking about "why wasn't this in the game at launch" and more appreciation that Shadows got it when it did to future proof the series. Parkour and Social Stealth are key foundations of the Assassin's Creed series. Now we're finally back to a reasonable and enjoyable version of Parkour. Let's bring back Social Stealth again.

Then we have critic of the game itself, which is the only part I care about. To be completely fair and objective, none of the AC games are terrible. This game does not feel like AC at all other than the hidden blade. For reference, I used to be obsessed with the AC franchise growing up; I played 1-3 and everything in between (Revelations, Brotherhood, etc). This game is a bit more enjoyable if you pretend it's just some adventure RPG held in feudal Japan. Other than that, it lacks a lot of aspects that I would've expected from an AC title; you can't even do the leap of faith from a sync point.

The story doesn't feel that captivating. I tried to be immersed and pay attention in the beginning, but at some point I just ended up skipping dialogue. The only thing that I would watch were the actual cinematic cut scenes. The side missions are so easy to dismiss that they don't feel worth doing unless they have equipment as reward.

If you don't have the fast travel unlocked, I hope you have a 2nd monitor or your phone nearby. I'm glad they give you a mount to use, and on top of that, allow to auto follow the road. Unfortunately, if the location you have to go is far without a fast travel, your horse is gonna be galloping for some time. There was a point where my destination was at a whole different, undiscovered area so I set my horse to auto-follow. I went downstairs to use the bathroom, prepared some food and eat, just to come back and find that I was barely passed halfway.

Some things that I did like:

I actually enjoyed the movement for Naoe. When I saw the trailer for movement, I was genuinely interested in the game. Even though it's not as fluid as I thought, it was still very enjoyable. 

The inventory/customization has got to be my favorite feature in this game. I like how you can change things from the handle, stilt, blade, and even sheathe of your katana, etc. to make it your own while keeping the stats of your equipped item.

The game does look nice. It did take some tweaking in the setting to prevent it from crashing all the time, but once I was able to play a few hours with no crash, it was enjoyable. 

Anyways, the main reason for the negative review is because Ubishit strikes again. I haven't played in about a week and I wanted to resume my playthrough. I had to log back in to my Ubisoft account and from then I was no longer able to open the game; not through Steam, Ubisoft client, or even the .exe file. Why does my massive samurai swinging a 5 foot spiked club get interrupted by a small guy kicking me. The world is big and pretty but it feels copy/paste with the same shrines/castles everywhere in every region. A few standout locations but probably could have been half the size and still been fine. If you want a samurai/ninja game play Ghost of Tsushima and if you already played that wait for a sale to pick this up.

Not Recommended

Just another flop from Ubisoft, what a surprise...

Now, don't get me wrong, this is much better than the last four "Assassin's Creed" "games". But it suffers from the fact that this is still not Assassin's Creed and the fact that this "game" is just another graphical showcase. If Ubisoft would spend five fucking minutes on ANYTHING other than graphics, then we would be good, but no.

To Ubisoft's credit, I actually don't outright hate the combat in this game. The combat is actually a little fun and engaging instead of outright enraging. I also Appreciate the customization in the settings. The fact that combat and stealth difficulties are separate, Canon Mode to give us the Assassin's Creed feel, Guaranteed Assassinations, etc. But that reminds me of a point I want to make. 

I like the fact that we can choose to make the hidden blade instakill (like it has been able to do for a decade straight for the first nine AC games...). But with the change to the combat system introduced in Origins, the drawn out fights with obnoxiously tanky enemies is getting really fucking old. Look, I get it. Combat for the first nine games was extremely easy (*cough cough* almost like the focus of Assassin's Creed is the story and not the combat *cough cough*). But being able to stab all the way through an enemy, deliver a salvo of devastating slashes, or shoot someone in the face, etc, and them continue on shafting you like nothing ever happened is a fantastic way to break the immersion. If you want difficult combat, then make combat focus on dodging, parrying, and penetrating armor instead of massive health pools. You know.. the historically accurate way to portray combat... 

Speaking of historical accuracy...

You know what? I could go on and on about the roots of Assassin's Creed and how it's always been about sticking purely to historical accuracy (with a few "minor" caveats). But that is just fruit hanging so damn low that it's practically a tripping hazard in hell. So I'll leave that point alone.

The two character system. It's much better than the two character system from Syndicate. But once I was able to play as Yasuke, I only did so for about 5 hours. The Yasuke play style is very different from Naoe's. It's actually really cool to play as a tanky Samurai with a flashy fighting style, cool animations, and good voice acting (in Japanese anyway. I turned on the Immersive Mode once I heard how terrible the english dub was). But Naoe is just the superior character since she has Eagle Vision, the Hidden Blade, and her grapple hook. She's also much better at parkour and stealth. It could be argued that Yasuke has his place since he's such a powerful warrior. But once you get good with the (rather complex) combat system, he just becomes almost completely irrelevant if it weren't for the story, side quests and side activities that require you to play as him. Plus, let's be honest here. This is Assassin's Creed. There is absolutely no place for a warrior with nigh to nill stealth and assassination capabilities.

Let's talk about graphics. Yeah. They're great. What do you expect? That's literally the only thing game developers have cared about for almost a decade at this point.

Story? Now THAT is a juicy topic! Assassin's Creed 2, Brotherhood, Revelations, 3, Black Flag, and Rogue were fucking MASTERPIECES. Ubisoft's story telling ability upright vanished over a decade ago. Or so I would believe if they didn't disprove that... It's not that they can't write a story. Hell, just about every single game with Assassin's Creed slapped on the front of it actually has a pretty good story, mediocre in the worst case scenarios. It's the fact that Ubisoft fucking REFUSES to present the story in a way that's comprehensible. Ubisoft has a fucking hardon for taking a perfectly good story and shuffling it around in such a way that it's nigh fucking impossible to understand it in the order that it's presented. So much fucking potential shot dead in the face because someone at Ubisoft is allergic to basic storytelling. Sorry for all the un-gentlemanly language in this section. But you can tell that I've been rubbed raw from years of games that could have been good if at least one person in charge of development didn't have a room temperature (or below) IQ.

Physics and parkour. Parkour is just about the only thing that has improved over time, aside from graphics. I remember being beside myself with rage when it came to the parkour in Black Flag and Rogue because Edward and Shay had a mind of their own. Which made chasing bad guys and sea shanties almost impossible. In Shadows, there are still a few rough spots, but it is much better overall. The physics is where I have an issue. the fact that momentum just isn't at all a concept when it comes to swinging on Naoe's rope, jumping into water from heights, and more, is yet another great way to instantly shatter any immersion that you once had. 

Animation. Great in most places, fantastic in some places, d0g$#1t in more places than it needs to be. I could go into detail, but I'm getting too tired to care. Ubisoft knows what they did, and if they don't, then it really doesn't matter. Because I'm pirating their titles until they unfck themselves to the point that Jesus Christ, the Lord and Savior himself, comes down from heaven just to nod his head in approval right before returning to the holy kingdom from where he came.

Other points. World: boring. Story (main and side): ignoring. Level system: snoring. Gameplay loop: choring. The Sake I bought to drink while playing this game: pouring. 

I probably only covered half of what I actually wanted to discuss. But I would much rather be playing a game that is actually fun instead of writing a review for a game that is little more than a sorry little cash grab.

Conclusion: Don't play unless you can find it for 90+% off or if you can find a pirated copy. I regret spending $40 for this less than mediocre game.

Probably the best modern Assassin's Creed game. yet it's ruined by a total lack of respect for the player's time. But it's really the Attack On Titans Questline that pushed me to make a review, as the game was neutral for me till now.

Ubisoft deserves some credit for stripping out much of the bloat this series has accrued over the last four games, making an effort to address the criticism of the "Ubisoft open world game" formula that players are tired of. 

Unfortunately, the result leaves you wondering, what's the point of such a massive and gorgeously-rendered open world if there's absolutely nothing to do in it? What's the point of a streamlined, simple gameplay loop if you're going to make the player do it hundreds of times over 50+ hours? 

If you're a Japanese history buff like me and love exploring for its own sake, and enjoyed the previous flawed games in the series, you'll probably have a decent time. There's the usual museum-like scenery and fun encounters with historical and legendary figures you've come to expect from the franchise. 

Otherwise, the game has nothing new to offer and doesn't do anything that other open world and stealth games, even other Japanese historical games like Ghost of Tsushima and Sekiro, don't already do better.
